description: I switched to Julia from R and my experience is great. Julia is fast and doesn't have ugly OOP unlike Python. Only functional programming with Multiple Dispatch.
summary: Great language for Big Data and Data Science

description: "Version 1.0.4" - is this a joke? We now have version 1.8
summary: "Version 1.0.4" - is this a joke? We now have version 1.8

description:
Julia is as simple as Matlab, yet even more beautiful and less clumpsy in style.
It is close to C in computation and has lots of libraries and available software. 
All in all hopefully the accepted future to scientific computing!
Best technical language

It's free, but still powerful! Wanted to learn Octave but saw good reviews for julia. It works great with a lot of features and packages. If you new to computing, learn julia today because it could be huge later on.
summary: Best alternative for matlab and Octave GNU

description: This will initialize the freedom for scientific computing. The power of the speed and accuracy will now be utilized and given back to people to create a better future. Love!

This language is fast, fun to write in and effortlessly does parallel execution. Fedora has a super up to date version that fixes a lot of the start up delays from the older versions in debian. 

Julia is super fun to use and very quick.

Add to Jupter Notebooks or Jupyter-Lab, by opening Julia in terminal and typing:

using Pkg
Pkg.add("IJulia")
Just be careful that the version provided here is 32 bit, but if you want to use CUDA, you may need a 64bit version.
Through the official website, there isn't even a 32-bits version for Linux. All in all, it's better to save the trouble and get the 64-bits option.
summary: 32 bits version, many features aren't compatible

description:

libgobject-2.0.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory

libgobject-2.0.so is installed by apt. How should I install libgobject-2.0 so that julia could see it?
summary: there is something that does not work

description: Note that the version here is an LTS release, and the most current as of this writing is 1.4.
Please update it

I have been using Julia for three years now. I use it for modelling robotics. and control systems. It's a compiled language that behaves like an interpreted language. It feels like Python but it's much faster. It allows functional programming very easily through its traits, structs and multiple dispatch. It enforces good design insisting on composition over inheritance. Many of the GOF design patterns are just the way you program in Julia. Use it with VSCode. Just don't install it from a PPA, instead download it from julia.org and don't forget to use GPG or SHA256 to check the integrity. Simply unzip the file and you're ready to go.
summary: Love it! But download the latest from julia.org
